description: From Anglo-Norman acquitance, Middle French aquitance, from acquiter (“to acquit”). Compare later acquittal.

entries.meaning: (now historical) A writing which is evidence of a discharge; a receipt in full, which bars a further demand. [from 14th c.]
(now rare) Payment of debt; settlement. [from 14th c.]
(now historical) The release from a debt, or from some obligation or duty; exemption. [from 14th c.]
(obsolete) The dismissal of a legal charge against someone; acquittal. [15th–19th c.]
examples: This was a task more difficult than that of self acquittance.

entries.meaning: (now rare) The acquittal of one's duties; the carrying out of fulfilment of a job or role. [from 17th c.]

verbs.description: acquittance (third-person singular simple present acquittances, present participle acquittancing, simple past and past participle acquittanced)
